elements.title: Verbal-to-Digital Language Continuity Across the Call-to-Website Handoff
elements.problem: The sales call builds cognitive ease through conversational language: Robert explains payment guarantees, damage deposits, and pricing in plain, concrete terms. But when the host transitions to the website to independently verify these claims (as Diane explicitly requests at 15:59: 'I want to read the whole website'), the language changes. Legal terminology, technical jargon, and formal copy replace the conversational register. Kahneman's research on illusions of truth shows that familiarity drives truth perception: 'A reliable way to make people believe in falsehoods is frequent repetition, because familiarity is not easily distinguished from truth.' The corollary is that when the website uses different words for the same concepts Robert explained, those concepts lose their truth-feeling. The host encounters the same value propositions but does not recognize them as the same claims she already accepted on the call, because the language has shifted. This creates a cognitive strain moment precisely when the host is performing independent verification.
elements.solution: Audit every key value proposition on the website against the language agents actually use on calls. Where they diverge, change the website to match the call language, not the other way around. Specifically: (1) The payment guarantee should use the exact phrasing Robert used: 'We guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you' -- not 'Split Lease acts as a payment intermediary facilitating transactions between parties.' (2) The damage deposit matching should say 'If the damage exceeds your deposit, we will match for the same amount' -- not 'Supplemental damage protection up to 100% of the security deposit.' (3) Create a language concordance document that maps every call-script phrase to its website equivalent, and enforce that the website version is no more than one register-level away from the call version. (4) Repeat the core value propositions in the same language at every phase transition: onboarding welcome, listing creation confirmation, pricing setup, and proposal receipt.

evidence.quote: You don't have to start the account. Anyway, if I want to, I want to read the whole website.
evidence.insight: Diane explicitly announces she will perform independent verification via the website before proceeding. This is the exact moment where language discontinuity between call and website will either build or destroy trust. She is about to compare what Robert said against what the website says.

evidence.quote: A reliable way to make people believe in falsehoods is frequent repetition, because familiarity is not easily distinguished from truth. The familiarity of one phrase in the statement sufficed to make the whole statement feel familiar, and therefore true.
evidence.insight: If the website repeats the exact phrases Robert used on the call, those phrases will feel familiar and therefore true. If the website paraphrases the same ideas in different words, the familiarity signal is lost and the claims must be re-evaluated from scratch by System 2.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, How to Write a Persuasive Message
evidence.quote: Do not use complex language where simpler language will do... couching familiar ideas in pretentious language is taken as a sign of poor intelligence and low credibility.
evidence.insight: If the website elevates Robert's plain language into formal or legal register, it does not merely lose familiarity -- it actively signals low credibility. The host interprets the formality as a lack of intelligence or an attempt to obscure, not as professionalism.

evidence.quote: We guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you. So you don't have to worry about collecting the payment from the guests... if the damage exceeds the $500, we will match for the same amount.
evidence.insight: These are the two core guarantees delivered in plain conversational language. They passed Diane's System 1 filter on the call. The website must present them in language close enough to this that her System 1 registers recognition, not novelty.

elements.user_goal: Verify on the website the same claims I heard on the call, and recognize them immediately as the same promises without having to decode new terminology.
elements.company_goal: Eliminate the trust gap at the call-to-website handoff that causes hosts to abandon onboarding after a successful sales call, by ensuring the website reinforces rather than undermines the cognitive ease the call built.
elements.time_budget: Within 30 seconds of landing on the website, the host should encounter at least one phrase she recognizes verbatim from the call. Within 2 minutes of browsing, she should have encountered all core value propositions in language that matches the call.
anti_goals: DO NOT let the legal team rewrite call-language value propositions into legal-register copy without a plain-language equivalent appearing first and prominently.
DO NOT assume that conveying the same meaning in different words is sufficient. Cognitive ease depends on recognition of the specific words, not comprehension of the underlying concept.
DO NOT create a separate 'marketing' voice for the website that diverges from how agents actually talk to hosts. The website voice should sound like the agent, not like a brand.
DO NOT bury the core guarantees in FAQ pages or terms of service. They must appear in the same prominent, conversational format the agent used.
elements.success_metric: Post-call website engagement rate: percentage of hosts who receive a follow-up link after a sales call and visit at least 3 pages on the website within 48 hours. Target: above 50%. Secondary: correlation between call-to-website language match score and onboarding completion rate.

elements.title: Experienced-Host Familiarity Trap Detection at Pricing and Lease Setup
elements.problem: Experienced hosts like Diane use pattern-matching from prior rental experience to evaluate the platform, and they conflate surface-level familiarity with genuine understanding. When Robert explains the pricing model (variable rates by nights-per-week, complementary schedule matching), Diane responds at 14:20: 'I just did all of that for years... I'm familiar.' But Split Lease's pricing model has unique elements she has never encountered: per-night rates that vary based on how many nights per week a guest books, complementary schedule matching between two part-time tenants, and week-over-week alternating occupancy. Kahneman's 'Illusions of Truth' research explains this: 'The familiarity of one phrase in the statement sufficed to make the whole statement feel familiar, and therefore true.' Diane recognizes 'nightly pricing' from her 15 years of hosting UN diplomats and maps the entire Split Lease model onto her existing mental model. The differences -- which are precisely what makes Split Lease's model work -- are invisible to her. This creates downstream failures when the actual pricing mechanics differ from what she expects.
elements.solution: At critical configuration points (pricing setup, lease term selection, schedule creation), introduce deliberate comprehension checkpoints that surface the differences between Split Lease's model and standard rental models. This means: (1) When a host sets pricing, show a concrete scenario with real numbers before confirming: 'If a guest books Monday-Thursday (4 nights) at your rate of $50/night, you earn $200/week. If a different guest books only Tuesday-Wednesday (2 nights) at your rate of $60/night, you earn $120/week. Confirm these are your preferred rates.' The scenario forces System 2 engagement with the specific mechanics. (2) Use 'Did you know?' friction points that briefly highlight what is different about Split Lease: 'Unlike nightly rentals, your guest signs a 3-6 month lease for specific days each week.' This is not general education -- it targets the specific assumptions an experienced host carries. (3) After the host confirms pricing, show a monthly projection that makes the complementary-schedule model concrete: 'With these rates, if both slots fill, your monthly income would be approximately $X.' (4) Use Kahneman's finding that cognitive strain activates System 2 to design these moments: a brief, deliberate friction that prevents false confidence from becoming a setup error.

evidence.quote: I just did all of that for years. I sold two co-ops on 54th and 52nd... I did it for 15 years, so I'm familiar.
evidence.insight: Diane declares familiarity immediately after hearing the pricing explanation, but her experience is with a fundamentally different model (nightly rentals to UN diplomats with no complementary scheduling). Her confidence signals that System 1 has accepted the model as known, which means System 2 will not scrutinize the differences.

evidence.quote: The familiarity of one phrase in the statement sufficed to make the whole statement feel familiar, and therefore true.
evidence.insight: The phrase 'per night' in Split Lease's pricing model is enough to make the entire model feel familiar to a host who has priced nightly rentals for 15 years. But the conditional structure (rate varies by number of nights booked per week) is genuinely novel and requires deliberate processing.

evidence.quote: If somebody says, I want only every week, but Monday through Thursday... then we will say, okay, how much per day you would want. If you have a person four nights, how much per day... and how much per day if you will have two nights.
evidence.insight: Robert's pricing explanation spans over a minute and involves multiple conditional scenarios. This complexity was navigable in conversation because Robert scaffolded it with examples. On the platform, without that scaffolding, the same complexity will either be oversimplified (host enters one flat rate) or overwhelming (host sees all options simultaneously).

evidence.quote: Performance was better with the bad font. Cognitive strain, whatever its source, mobilizes System 2, which is more likely to reject the intuitive answer suggested by System 1.
evidence.insight: Deliberate friction at the pricing confirmation step is beneficial. A brief moment of cognitive strain -- showing the host a concrete scenario that reveals how Split Lease pricing differs from standard nightly pricing -- mobilizes System 2 to catch configuration errors before they cause problems during active leases.

elements.user_goal: Set up pricing that accurately reflects my expectations for income, without discovering weeks later that the model works differently from what I assumed.
elements.company_goal: Prevent experienced hosts from misconfiguring pricing due to false familiarity, which leads to disputes, repricing friction, and churn during active leases when the actual economics diverge from the host's assumptions.
elements.time_budget: The comprehension checkpoint should add no more than 60 seconds to the pricing setup flow. It should present one concrete scenario with real numbers, require one confirmation click, and show one monthly projection.
anti_goals: DO NOT treat experienced hosts as beginners. The checkpoint should acknowledge their expertise ('You likely set nightly rates before -- here is what is different about Split Lease pricing') rather than teaching them what nightly pricing is.

DO NOT add friction everywhere. This pattern applies specifically to moments where Split Lease's model differs from standard rental models. If a feature works the same way hosts already expect, do not add a checkpoint.
DO NOT make the checkpoint feel like a quiz or test. It should feel like a preview of what will actually happen, not a test of whether the host understood the instructions.
DO NOT assume the host read or retained the pricing explanation from the sales call. The checkpoint must be self-contained.
elements.success_metric: Pricing revision rate within the first 30 days: percentage of hosts who change their pricing after the first guest proposal or booking. Target: below 15%. Current baseline (if available) should be measured before implementing the checkpoint.

elements.title: Zero-Effort Listing Import as the Default Path for Experienced Hosts
elements.problem: Experienced multi-property hosts like Diane already have listings on other platforms. Asking them to recreate this information from scratch on a new platform is pure cognitive waste -- it produces no new value and consumes System 2 resources that have already been spent once. Robert offers two paths: create your own listing, or provide a link and the team pulls the data (10:32-11:03). But both paths are presented as equal options. For an experienced host with existing listings, the import path is not just a convenience -- it is the only path consistent with cognitive ease. Kahneman's principle that 'anything you can do to reduce cognitive strain will help' applies directly: the import path eliminates strain entirely for the listing content, while the manual path multiplies strain across every property. For Diane with three properties, the difference is not 1x versus 1x -- it is 0x effort versus 3x effort.
elements.solution: Make the listing import path the default and primary experience for any host who indicates prior listing experience. This means: (1) During onboarding or the sales call, ask one qualifying question: 'Do you already have listings on another site?' If yes, the import path activates automatically. The manual creation path becomes the secondary option, not the other way around. (2) When the import is complete, send the host a single verification task per property -- not a full listing editor, but a summary card showing key details (photos, price, description) with a single 'Looks good' or 'Edit' choice. The verification must feel like approval, not like work. (3) For multi-property hosts, batch the verification: show all imported listings on a single screen with individual approve/edit toggles, so the host can verify three properties in one session rather than three separate sessions. (4) If the imported data is incomplete, pre-fill what was imported and highlight only the gaps. Do not present the full form with some fields filled and others empty -- present a nearly-complete listing with specific callouts for what is missing.

evidence.quote: Option number two, you tell me here's the pictures or here's the link I'm already listing it somewhere... We take that information from that site for you, create your listings, send you back links to your listings, and then you go in and you verify if you like everything.
evidence.insight: Robert describes the import path as just one of two equal options, but for a host like Diane who has existing listings on multiple platforms, the import path eliminates virtually all listing creation effort. The platform should recognize this asymmetry and default to import for experienced hosts.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, How to Write a Persuasive Message
evidence.quote: The general principle is that anything you can do to reduce cognitive strain will help, so you should first maximize legibility.
evidence.insight: The broadest application of this principle is not about fonts or colors -- it is about eliminating unnecessary cognitive work entirely. Asking a host to re-enter information that already exists elsewhere is creating cognitive strain from nothing. The import path reduces strain to its theoretical minimum: review and approve.

evidence.quote: It's unbelievable. You know, the day is never long enough.
evidence.insight: Diane's extreme time poverty means the difference between import and manual creation is likely the difference between completing listing creation and abandoning it. She has three properties to list. If each requires 10-15 minutes of manual entry, the total is 30-45 minutes. If each requires 2 minutes of verification, the total is 6 minutes. Only the 6-minute path is compatible with her schedule.

evidence.quote: We do not charge you... all our income comes from markup to the guests. So if nothing happens, all you lose is the time you spent.
evidence.insight: Robert frames the risk as 'only your time.' But for a time-poor host, time IS the primary cost. The import path reduces this cost to near-zero, making the no-risk framing genuinely true rather than technically true.

elements.user_goal: Get my existing properties listed on Split Lease without redoing work I have already done on other platforms, and verify the results in minutes, not hours.
elements.company_goal: Maximize listing creation completion rates for multi-property experienced hosts by reducing the effort to near-zero, converting the highest-value host segment (multiple properties, proven track record) that would otherwise abandon due to time constraints.
elements.time_budget: The host should spend no more than 2 minutes per property on listing verification after import. For a 3-property host like Diane, total listing creation time should be under 10 minutes including the initial link submission.
anti_goals: DO NOT present import and manual creation as equal options. For hosts with existing listings, import should be the default path with manual creation available as a fallback.
DO NOT show the host a full listing editor after import. Show a summary card with an approval action. Only open the editor if the host explicitly chooses to edit.
DO NOT require the host to verify each property in a separate session or on a separate page. Batch verification for multi-property hosts.
DO NOT import listing data and then require the host to re-enter information that was already captured in the import. If the import got the bedroom count, do not ask for the bedroom count again.
elements.success_metric: Listing completion rate for hosts with existing listings on other platforms: percentage who complete at least one listing within 7 days of the sales call. Target: above 70%. Secondary: average number of listings per multi-property host within 14 days.

elements.title: Host Agency Preservation in Pre-Created Account Flows
elements.problem: Robert offers to pre-create Diane's account (10:07: 'I will also create your account on site. I'll send you a temporary password'). This is intended as a cognitive ease intervention -- removing the signup barrier. But Diane pushes back (15:59: 'I want to read the whole website' before proceeding). The pre-creation pattern fails because it removes agency from a host whose System 2 is still engaged and wants to verify before committing. Kahneman's framework explains why: cognitive strain from novelty has not yet been resolved. When a host is in a strained state ('you are more likely to be vigilant and suspicious'), having decisions made for them does not reduce strain -- it increases suspicion. The pre-created account feels like a fait accompli rather than a convenience. The host perceives a loss of control, which triggers the opposite of cognitive ease.
elements.solution: Redesign the pre-created account flow to preserve host agency while still reducing friction. This means: (1) Instead of creating the account and sending a password, send a personalized invitation link that shows the host what has been prepared but requires their explicit action to activate: 'Robert has prepared your account. Click here to review and activate when you are ready.' The preparation is done, but the host initiates. (2) The invitation landing page should show what the agent prepared (property addresses, imported listing drafts, agent's contact) without requiring login. The host can browse and evaluate before deciding to activate. This satisfies Diane's desire to 'read the whole website' while also showing her the account is ready. (3) Never frame the pre-creation as something that has already been decided. Use language that positions the host as the activator: 'Your account is ready for you to claim' versus 'Your account has been created.' (4) Allow the host to set the pace. Do not send follow-up emails pressuring activation within a specific timeframe.

evidence.quote: Well, you can, I don't mind give it to you, but let me read you a written first. You don't have to start. You start the account. Anyway, if I want to, I want to read the whole website.
evidence.insight: Diane explicitly resists the pre-created account. She wants to verify before anything is done on her behalf. This is a System 2 demand for verification, and the platform must respect it or risk triggering the vigilance-and-suspicion cluster that Kahneman describes as the opposite of cognitive ease.

evidence.quote: When you feel strained, you are more likely to be vigilant and suspicious, invest more effort in what you are doing, feel less comfortable, and make fewer errors, but you also are less intuitive and less creative than usual.
evidence.insight: Diane is in a strained state: she is evaluating a new, unfamiliar platform. In this state, having her account pre-created without her consent does not ease the strain -- it triggers the vigilance and suspicion that Kahneman associates with cognitive strain. The intervention must wait until the host has reached a state of cognitive ease through her own verification process.

evidence.quote: What should I look for? What's the name of it?
evidence.insight: Even after a 17-minute call, Diane does not know the platform name well enough to find it on her own. The brand has not yet achieved the mere-exposure familiarity threshold. Pre-creating an account on a platform the host cannot even name independently signals a mismatch between the agent's confidence in the platform and the host's current relationship with it.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, The Pleasure of Cognitive Ease
evidence.quote: The mere exposure effect occurs because the repeated exposure of a stimulus is followed by nothing bad. Such a stimulus will eventually become a safety signal, and safety is good.
evidence.insight: The host needs repeated safe exposures to the platform before an account feels appropriate. The first exposure should be browsing the website without commitment. The second exposure should be seeing the prepared account. The third should be activating it. Each exposure, followed by nothing bad, builds the safety signal that makes commitment feel natural rather than forced.

elements.user_goal: Explore and verify the platform on my own terms before any account or commitment is created in my name, and feel that I am the one choosing to proceed at every step.
elements.company_goal: Increase onboarding completion by redesigning the pre-created account flow to respect host agency, converting hosts who currently drop off because they feel pushed rather than invited.
elements.time_budget: The invitation link should be explorable in under 2 minutes without requiring any login or signup action. The host should be able to go from browsing to activation in under 60 seconds when they are ready.
anti_goals: DO NOT create accounts without the host's explicit request or confirmation. Prepare the account, but let the host activate it.
DO NOT send the temporary password in the first email. The first email should be an invitation to browse, not a demand to log in.
DO NOT interpret the host's delay in activating as disinterest. Diane's pattern (verify first, then act) is a high-quality engagement pattern, not a dropout signal.
DO NOT pressure the host with follow-up emails about the pre-created account. One invitation, one gentle reminder after 5-7 days, then wait for the host to act.
elements.success_metric: Invitation-to-activation rate: percentage of hosts who receive a prepared account invitation and activate within 14 days. Target: above 40%. Secondary: compare activation rates between pre-created-with-password (current) and prepared-invitation (new) approaches.

elements.title: Cumulative Safety Signal Design Through Visible Positive Repetition
elements.problem: Host retention depends on cumulative cognitive ease: each successful payment, uneventful guest stay, and smooth interaction builds the platform into a 'safety signal' through mere exposure. But most platforms make successful interactions invisible -- payments deposit silently, uneventful stays produce no feedback, and smooth interactions leave no trace. Kahneman's research on the mere exposure effect shows that 'the repeated exposure of a stimulus is followed by nothing bad. Such a stimulus will eventually become a safety signal.' But for this to work, the host must be conscious of the repeated positive exposures. Diane's prior experience illustrates the stakes: she had 'pretty good people, steady' for years (06:23), but when COVID disrupted payments, she had no reservoir of visible positive history to weigh against the disruption. Each successful month had been invisible, so the failures dominated her memory. The platform must make the positive repetitions visible to build a defensible safety signal.
elements.solution: Design the active lease experience to make every successful interaction a visible, recorded exposure that accumulates into a trust record. This means: (1) After every successful payment, show the host a brief confirmation that includes a running count: 'Payment received -- 4 of 6 months completed successfully.' This makes the positive pattern salient. (2) At the end of each guest stay or lease cycle, generate a brief summary: 'Lease completed. 0 damage claims. 6/6 payments on time. Guest rating: 4.8.' This is the host's evidence that the platform works. (3) On the host dashboard, display a 'track record' section that shows the cumulative history of successful transactions across all properties. For a multi-property host like Diane, this compounds: 3 properties x 6 months = 18 visible positive events. (4) When a negative event does occur (late payment, damage claim), the visible history of positive events provides context. Instead of 'There is a problem,' the message is '17 of 18 payments on time. One payment is 3 days late -- here is what we are doing about it.' The positive history cushions the negative event.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, The Pleasure of Cognitive Ease
evidence.quote: The consequences of repeated exposures benefit the organism in its relations to the immediate animate and inanimate environment. They allow the organism to distinguish objects and habitats that are safe from those that are not, and they are the most primitive basis of social attachments.
evidence.insight: Retention is the outcome of the platform becoming a safety signal through repeated positive exposure. But exposure must be conscious and salient to build the safety signal. Silent successes are missed exposures -- the host's System 1 cannot form a positive association with something it never noticed.

evidence.quote: COVID made the mess... I had pretty good people, steady... some moved out, didn't pay a few more months.
evidence.insight: Diane's years of successful rentals left no visible record. When the disruption came, she had no accumulated evidence of reliability to weigh against the losses. If a platform had shown her '47 of 48 months paid on time' before the disruption, the context would have made the failure feel like an exception rather than a pattern collapse.

evidence.quote: We guarantee that we will collect the payment and pay you. So you don't have to worry about collecting the payment from the guests.
evidence.insight: The payment guarantee is the core promise. Every successful payment is proof that the guarantee works. But proof that is invisible (money deposited silently) builds less trust than proof that is visible (confirmation with running count). The guarantee must be actively demonstrated, not just passively honored.

evidence.quote: A good mood is a signal that things are generally going well, the environment is safe, and it is all right to let one's guard down.
evidence.insight: Each visible positive event reinforces the host's good mood about the platform. The cumulative effect is that the host's default state becomes ease rather than vigilance. This makes renewal and re-listing a System 1 decision (automatic, effortless) rather than a System 2 decision (deliberate, effortful).

elements.user_goal: See clear evidence that the platform is working for me -- that payments are arriving, properties are protected, and my experience is building a track record of success.
elements.company_goal: Increase host retention and multi-lease renewals by making the cumulative value of the platform visible, so that the renewal decision is driven by a strong safety signal rather than a fresh cost-benefit analysis.
elements.time_budget: Payment confirmation should appear within 5 seconds of the payment processing. Lease completion summaries should arrive within 24 hours of the lease end. The track record dashboard should load in under 2 seconds and be visible on the host's default landing page.
anti_goals: DO NOT make successful payments invisible. Every payment is an opportunity to reinforce the safety signal.
DO NOT over-notify. One confirmation per event is sufficient. The goal is visible evidence, not notification fatigue.
DO NOT present negative events without the context of the positive track record. A late payment in isolation triggers panic. A late payment against 17 on-time payments triggers proportionate concern.
DO NOT limit the track record to the current lease. Show the full history across all properties and all leases to maximize the cumulative safety signal.
elements.success_metric: Lease renewal rate: percentage of hosts who renew or re-list after completing their first lease. Target: above 60%. Secondary: correlation between number of visible positive events (payment confirmations opened, summaries viewed) and renewal rate.

elements.title: Time-Poor Host Design: Every Interaction Under 2 Minutes or Async
elements.problem: Diane represents a host profile where extreme time poverty is the dominant constraint. She describes her schedule as 'the day is never long enough' (00:49) and manages multiple properties across Manhattan and Queens. For this host type, any platform interaction that requires more than a few minutes of focused attention will be deferred indefinitely. Kahneman's insight that 'System 2 is lazy and mental effort is aversive' combines with time poverty to create a compounding effect: not only is the mental effort aversive, but there is no time slot in which to exert it. The standard design assumption -- that the user will sit down and complete a multi-step process in one session -- fails for time-poor multi-property hosts. Every task that cannot be completed in the margin of a busy day (waiting for a call, riding the subway, between meetings) will never be completed at all.
elements.solution: Design every host-facing interaction to be completable in under 2 minutes, or to be fully asynchronous with save-and-resume. This means: (1) Break every multi-step process into atomic tasks that can each be completed in under 2 minutes. Listing verification: 2 minutes. Pricing setup for one property: 2 minutes. Proposal review: 2 minutes. Each task should have a clear start, a clear end, and produce a visible result. (2) Send task prompts via the channel the host already uses (text, email) with direct deep links that open to the exact task, not to a dashboard that requires navigation. Diane should receive a text: 'Your Manhattan listing is ready to verify -- tap here to review (2 min).' (3) Allow every task to be abandoned and resumed without data loss. If the host starts pricing setup and gets interrupted after 45 seconds, the 45 seconds of work must be preserved. (4) For multi-property hosts, sequence tasks across properties rather than requiring all at once: 'Verify Manhattan listing today, Queens listings tomorrow.' Spread the effort across multiple short sessions rather than requiring one long session. (5) Never require the host to be at a computer. Every task must be completable on a phone screen.

evidence.quote: It's unbelievable. You know, the day is never long enough to do the new Exactly.
evidence.insight: Diane's time constraint is not temporary or situational -- it is structural. She manages multiple properties, handles her own operations, and is constantly busy. The platform cannot ask her to find 30 minutes. It must fit into the 2-minute gaps that exist in her day.

evidence.source: kahneman-cognitive-ease.txt, How to Write a Persuasive Message
evidence.quote: System 2 is lazy and that mental effort is aversive. If possible, the recipients of your message want to stay away from anything that reminds them of effort.
evidence.insight: For a time-poor host, the mere perception of effort is enough to defer a task. If the platform presents a listing creation flow that looks like it will take 15 minutes, the host will not start it -- not because the effort is too great, but because the perceived effort exceeds the time she has available right now.

evidence.quote: I have an apartment in Manhattan and I have two buildings in Queens.
evidence.insight: Three properties multiply every time cost. If each property requires a 15-minute setup session, the total is 45 minutes of focused platform time. If each requires a 2-minute verification, the total is 6 minutes spread across three convenient moments. Only the second pattern is compatible with Diane's schedule.

evidence.quote: Cognitive strain is experienced when the effortful operations of System 2 are engaged.
evidence.insight: Time poverty amplifies cognitive strain because there is no recovery time between effortful tasks. A host who completes one 10-minute task and immediately faces another has compounded strain. A host who completes a 2-minute task and returns to her day recovers fully before the next 2-minute task.

elements.user_goal: Complete every platform task in the small time gaps in my busy day, without needing to set aside a dedicated session or remember where I left off.
elements.company_goal: Capture the multi-property experienced host segment that currently drops off during onboarding and listing creation due to time constraints, by designing flows that fit their actual schedule rather than an idealized one.
elements.time_budget: No single task should require more than 2 minutes of focused attention. Multi-property workflows should be sequenced into separate 2-minute tasks spread across hours or days, not bundled into one session.
anti_goals: DO NOT design flows that assume the host will complete them in one sitting. Every flow must support interruption and resumption.
DO NOT require the host to navigate to a task. Deliver the task to the host via deep link in the channel she already uses.
DO NOT show progress bars that imply a long process ahead. Show the current task and its estimated completion time only.
DO NOT batch multi-property tasks into a single session unless the host explicitly chooses to do so. Default to spreading them out.
elements.success_metric: Task completion rate for multi-property hosts: percentage of individual tasks (listing verification, pricing setup, proposal review) completed within 48 hours of being sent. Target: above 65%. Secondary: average time-to-complete per task (target: under 2 minutes).
